title: 111_s3954
content: The "Air Cargo Security Act" is the short title of the Act. It mandates the inspection of cargo carried on all-cargo aircraft. Section 44901(f) of title 49, United States Code, is amended to establish a system for screening and inspecting all cargo on all-cargo aircraft to ensure security, with minimum standards approved by the Transportation Security Administration. The Air Cargo Security Act mandates the screening of passenger checked baggage to ensure security. The Secretary must ensure that 50% of cargo is screened within 18 months and 100% within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Additionally, the Secretary is responsible for monitoring and evaluating new technologies for cargo screening. The Secretary is responsible for monitoring and evaluating the research and development of effective cargo screening technologies. SEC. 3. AIR CARGO SHIPPING. Regular inspections of air cargo shipping facilities will be established to ensure security controls are observed for cargo transported by air. The Secretary of Homeland Security will work with foreign authorities to implement these inspections. The Air Cargo Security Act mandates regular screening and inspection of cargo at shipping facilities in foreign countries for air transportation to the United States. The term 'screening' refers to air cargo inspection procedures required by law. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit reports to Congress detailing the number of inspected facilities, non-compliant facilities, and consequences imposed for non-compliance. The Secretary may increase air cargo inspectors to ensure screenings and inspections of cargo transported to the United States. Amendments are made to the chapter analysis for chapter 449 of title 49, United States Code. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish a training program for cargo handlers to ensure proper handling and security of air cargo. The Act and its amendments will take effect 180 days after enactment.
